newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Police probe WMC explosive finds.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Police probe WMC explosive finds.

text.p: Police on Monday said they were still investigating explosives found at homes of two WMC Ltd managers in the mining town of Kambalda.

A parcel of three gelignite-like sticks were found on Friday on the verandah of one manager's house, Detective Tom Cagan of the Kalgoorlie Police Department told Reuters. About one hour later, a second parcel was found on the windshield of the car parked at a house in Kambalda of another manager, Cagan said.
Earlier this month, WMC, one of Australia's largest mining companies, announced it was laying off 445 workers in the Kambalda region, where it mines nickel and gold.
Cragan would not comment on whether there was a connection between the explosives being found and the job cuts.
The explosives did not contain detonating devices.
The Australian Mine Workers Union distanced the union from the incidents.

"I don't know whether there is any connection at all," spokesman Bob Krygsman said. "You don't have to be a Rhodes Scholar to see it is a form of intimidation, but its certainly something we would not condone," Krygsman added.
At the time of the layoffs, WMC said it expected most of the affected workes to be re-hired by independent mining contractors.
Krygsman said it remained uncertain how many workers would be rehired.
About 70 unfair dismissal claims have been filed by laid off workers with the government's Industrial Relations Commission.
Krygsman said mining contractors have said it will be about six weeks before mining operations at Kambalda return to normal.
